awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Measuring Attention, Working Memory, and Visual Perception To Reduce Risk of Injuries in the Construction Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
Human error (e.g., poor decisions or unsafe actions) are a main casual factor in up to 80% of all workplace accidents across a breadth of industries. To the extent our limited capacity for information processing capacity is a major source of such errors, better understanding of cognitive processes will yield more effective methods for predicting and reducing the poor decisions that put workers at risk. Accordingly, this study will complete a series of eye-tracking experiments to build an error-detection framework - the Human-Error Detection Framework - that computes the likelihood of human error in occupational settings to enable proactive countermeasures to keep workers safe. Subsequently, to extend the value of this framework, this project will enrich and expand research-based educational materials, outreach, and engagement activities to spread awareness about this framework to communities and workers. To achieve these goals, this multidisciplinary project blends research linking eye movements and workers' attention with research focused on working-memory load and decision making in order to discover how and why workers in dynamic work environments fail to detect, comprehend, and/or respond to physical risks. Using the dynamic and high-risk environment of construction as a testbed, the proposed framework will connect eye movements and cognitive manipulations in laboratory and field experiments with worker demographics to identify precursors that predict accident-causing human errors in dynamic worksites. In all, this project will demonstrate the value and effectiveness of synthesizing cognitive psychology, engineering, and advanced computation to improve decision making and occupational safety.


The Human-Error Detection Framework will harness real-time eye-movement patterns to identify human errors and thereby lay the foundation for synthesizing technology with data analysis to automatically identify and interrupt human decision-making errors before injuries occur. Using the predictive models resulting from this study will not only contribute to significant accident reduction but will also provide a critical validation measure to confirm the effectiveness of training programs in enhancing workers' risk-analysis skills. Furthermore, since this project provides tools and insights for researchers, students, and workers to use to enhance occupational safety and multidisciplinary research, this project will evolve the broader pedagogical landscape of the decision, risk, and management sector. As this innovative research challenges the conventional, reactionary paradigm of safety-risk management by enabling the identification of at-risk workers using a measurable indicator of their cognitive processes, i.e., their eye movements, the proposed proactive approach to occupational safety has the potential for averting occupational accidents across industries and thereby will foreseeably prevent the injuries that undermine the well-being of millions of American workers and their families.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: 

By focusing on the connection between attention, working memory, and eye movements, multiple eye-tracking experiments in both the laboratory and the field were implemented that provided important insight into how and why construction workers fail to detect or comprehend a hazardous situation.  Specifically, a few metrics have been highlighted that can help to identify at-risk workers (e.g., first fixation time, run count, dwell-time), along with the importance of work experience, training, injury exposure, personality, and risk-taking behavior.

 

Intellectual merits:

The project applied and expanded theories in cognitive psychology and risk-taking behavior to understand and predict the likelihood of human error among workers in a dynamic environment. There are several key novel findings, based on empirical experiments that collected eye tracking metrics and other variables, that have enriched the literature in, particularly, human factors, cognitive psychology, and risk management & decision making. Here we highlight some of them in each area.

Human Factors:

  • There is minimal difference in identifying hazards with or without the Occupational Safety and Health Administration 10-h certificate; while relative to less experienced workers (10 years), experienced workers need less processing time to assess hazards and deploy more frequent short fixations on hazardous areas to maintain situational awareness of the environment; and injury exposure history significantly impacts a worker?s visual search strategy and attentional allocation.
  • Workers? personality dimensions?specifically, extraversion, conscientiousness, and openness to experience?significantly relate to and impact attentional allocation and the search strategies of workers exposed to fall hazards. Individuals who are introverted, more conscientious, or more open to experience are less prone to injury and return their attention more frequently to hazardous areas.
  • Individuals with more work experience and safety training are better at hazard identification, regardless of personality. Furthermore, individual differences in conscientiousness and openness personality dimensions significantly moderate the associations between (1) worker characteristics and visual attention; and (2) visual attention and hazard identification.
  • Subjects do not allocate their attention equally to all hazardous areas of interest, and these differences in attentional distribution were modulated by the workers? level of situation awareness.

Cognitive Psychology:

  • Hazard identification performance deteriorates when workers must maintain a working memory load and higher loads lead to worse performance.
  • Hazard identification skills significantly impact workers? visual search strategies: workers with higher hazard-identification skills had lower dwell-time percentages on ladder-related hazards; higher fixation counts on fall-to-lower-level hazards; and higher fixation counts and run counts on fall-protection systems, struck-by, housekeeping, and all hazardous areas combined. It is found that certain eye-movement metrics (e.g., fixation count) uniquely discriminates workers with high hazard-identification skills and at-risk workers. This study provides a proof of concept that certain eye-movement metrics are predictive indicators of human error due to attentional failure.
  • Worker?s hazard identification abilities are affected by the static and/or dynamic nature of hazards and workers better anticipate dynamic hazards thanks to target and context anticipatory cues.
  • As workers with higher situation awareness walk, they periodically look down and obtain feedforward information (e.g., scan ahead) to remain fully aware of the environment and its associated hazards.

Risk Management & Decision Making:

  • The results reveal that construction workers may be at a heightened risk because of a time pressure-induced reduction in efficient attentional allocation to hazardous areas of interest. In addition, time pressure resulted in a trade-off between safety and productivity as participants strived to balance the costs (e.g., fall and hand injuries) and benefits (productivity bonus and timesaving) associated with the task.
  • Safety-relevant changes are detected significantly faster than safety-irrelevant changes, with certain types of fall hazards (e.g., unprotected edge hazards) being detected faster than other types (e.g., ladder hazards). In addition, more experienced workers achieve higher accuracy in detecting relevant changes, but this is offset by a longer response time.

 

Broader impacts:

By focusing on advancing scientific knowledge that will prevent injuries and fatalities in an industry with a disproportionate injury rate, the project?s findings have the potential to improve the well-being of millions of American workers and their families. An understanding of the fundamental nature of human error due to cognitive failure will allow future researchers to produce smart personal protective equipment that can be used to identify workers who are more susceptible to erroneous decisions and accidents. Providing empirical evidence for the pivotal role of worker characteristics and dispositional traits regarding hazard-identification performance on jobsites, this project also supports personalized safety training that targets at-risk workers in the construction industry and beyond. The findings of the project have been broadly disseminated to the research (e.g., ASCE) and practice (e.g., CII, AGC) communities. Graduate students actively participated in the research, conducting experiments, analyzing data, and developing error detection algorithms. They also were also involved in developing hands-on activities and teaching/guiding undergraduate and K-12 students through them. The developed modules from this project have been incorporated into the curriculum at George Mason University.
